2502: Dreams of the Dead.author: Ragamander
2502: Dreams of the Dead.text_parsed:
Not a bad card, especially since it lets you instantly generate necessary blockers from your dead creatures. For only two mana, just having them for a single block isn't a terrible deal. The only thing a bit restrictive is the four-mana down-payment on your reanimation engine. Running it with Eon Hub makes it flat-out amazing, since you won't ever see that new upkeep cost come back to haunt you. Combine also with Momentary Blink or a creature like Saltskitter for more lulz, since the creature will return as a new creature, able to be reanimated again should it die.

Overall, I think it's an excellent (but not tournament-competitive) card in the right deck and a decent card in any correctly-colored, creature-based deck (Esper, Azorius, Dimir). I am going to have to consider playing it.

2506: Force Void.author: scumbling1
2506: Force Void.text_parsed:
"Comparing this to Mana Leak or Force Spike is overlooking the fact that this draws you a card. Mana Leak and Force Spike don't draw you a card. Counter a spell and draw a card for 3 mana is pretty good."

Overwhelming Intellect draws you many cards, but it's expense and situational nature make it bad.

It's much the same for Force Void. The reason Daze and Force Spike see any play is that they come online early enough to stop turn one plays, and are easy to hold ready for catching a tapped-out opponent. Holding three mana open is a lot considering the opponent has only to hold open one to play around it. While Mana Leak doesn't come online as early, it still asks the opponent to have more mana open to them than it does of you.

2512: Illusionary Presence.author: longwinded
2512: Illusionary Presence.text_parsed:
@Gradius: yes. Before the notion of subtypes and supertypes were added to the game -- that is, back when all you had was creature types, before that was generalized into subtypes for lands, artifact creatures, and other spells -- all that mattered was a land's name. "Landwalk ability of your choice" could be "Urza's Towerwalk" just as easily as "forestwalk" or "swampwalk". IIRC, "Island of Wak-Wak-walk" actually came up in a tournament, because the opponent was on the defensive with non-flying blockers and Island of Wak-Wak. I vaguely remember another component -- did he have Island Sanctuary and desperately need the card draw? Did he sacrifice all of his basic lands? -- but it's oddly difficult to find the specifics online these days.

When subtypes were introduced and land types were created, they added subtypes for Urza's Tower, Urza's Mine, and Urza's Factory, so that the old style of play would still be legal for older lands. Still, they had to draw the line somewhere, and it was at Island of Wak-Wak.

It should also be noted that, since all that mattered was name, the dual lands needed special "counts as both a swamp/plains/etc. and a forest/island/etc." rules text. Also, Island of Wak-Wak was the first card where they could officially rule that a land with island (or any basic land name) in its name is not necessarily an island (or other land type) under the rules. All three of these issues, as well as clarifying what the text of transformative spells like Conversion meant, are why subtypes were eventually added for the land type.

My first ever game of Magic, we played simply with the 60-card 5-colour random starter decks.

Game turned to a standoff until I drew this, and - since we did not know the rules well - proceeded to smack the hell out of my opponent with an amazing flying wall. Since we really did not know the rules well, we did not know the meaning of cumulative either, so I just payed {U} every upkeep until my opponent was dead and I won whatever cards were in the ante because the rulebook said to play for ante.

Then he showed me how to smoke cigarettes.

The art is incredible, however.

2519: Mesmeric Trance.author: The_Murderauder
2519: Mesmeric Trance.text_parsed:
Oracle wording ruined this card. I fully believe that if the discard had been part of the effect, and not the cost, this card would still be balanced. And hey, maybe actually good! You could then, when you had an empty hand, pay to draw a card, play it, then pay to draw another.

As it is now, you can't even activate the ability if you don't have a card in hand. So this is guaranteed to always be card neutrality (at best), and never card advantage.

The only decks that could really "break" it (storm, high tide, legacy and vintage junk) are already broken, and have much better things to do anyway.

With 3 CMC to cast, cumulative upkeep, and a minimum of to get +1 card (if you're ALREADY in topdeck mode), this would still be entirely fair.

Wizards! Revisit this Oracle text!
2519: Mesmeric Trance.text_posted:

As it is now, you can't even activate the ability if you don't have a card in hand. So this is [i]guaranteed[/i] to always be card neutrality (at best), and never card advantage.

2521: Musician.author: majinara
2521: Musician.text_parsed:
What's nice about the dude:
You can tap him in response to the cumulative upkeep trigger, so even if you never pay the upkeep cost, you can tap him at least once. Also, the counters including the "pay or sac" ability stay active, even once the musician is gone. Paying 1 doesn't sound much, but each time you tap him, he either acts as a stone rain, denying mana, or as a creature killer.
Not a great card, but fun in some decks.

2521: Musician.author: Lord_of_Tresserhorn
2521: Musician.text_parsed:
The Oracle text makes it clear that:

a) The creature gains the ability permanently as long as it is on the battlefield. It loses it neither when Musician leaves play or when all Music counters are removed.
b) It is not possible to give it the ability (well, cost) twice, since these would stack.

It's not weird, it's a correct wording.

Also, pretty cool creature. The flavor may have something to do with using magical music to force the other creatures to "dance" which makes them more and more "tired" until they "fall over". Though in that case, it would have made sense to remove all music counters when Musician leaves play (and the ensnaring song ends).

Also, proliferate. Using Contagion Engine is like flooding the market with cheap pop music. :P

2522: Mystic Might.author: PineappleDisciple
2522: Mystic Might.text_parsed:
If this was just a sorcery that cost 1U and read "Target creature gets +2/+2 until end of turn" it wouldn't be too bad. This can do much more than that. If you tap the enchanted land the second turn it's out before paying the cumulative upkeep, then you're spending 2U and getting +4+/+4 in total buffs.

If you have a way to untap lands (Cloud of Faeries, Hidden Strings, or Captain of the Mists for example) you can get tons of extra value out of it. And in the late game you might be running out of things to do with your mana anyways; this give a blue deck a way to convert its extra mana into damage.

Considering how rare blue pump is, I like this card.

Admittedly, this big fella dies to Terror, Swords, and other such removal, but he still puts opponents on a short clock if he comes out early. Surpassed by modern creature design, but probably one of the most playable of the early huge blue creatures. Oh, and November 11, 2011 is Polar Kraken Day! Or, at least it should be, if Magic had official holidays.

2526: Portent.author: igniteice
2526: Portent.text_parsed: I've seen this ran with Cosi's Trickster and Psychic Surgery, both of which can be dropped fairly quickly. You can get a Cosi's Trickster out on turn 1. Turn 2 drop an Island, a Sol Ring, and another Cosi's Trickster. Turn 3 play a third island, play two Psychic Surgerys, then cast Portent on your opponent. You now have two 2/2s and you've exiled two cards and stacked the next two draws for your opponent, more so if they're playing fetch lands.

2528: Ray of Command.author: Equinox523
2528: Ray of Command.text_parsed: This is an excellent card, and an ability that has since migrated to red in the form of Threaten and its ilk. It can set up so many weird situations, including grabbing attackers and using them to block others, or to surprise an opponent and attack them with their own just-summoned beast. Hell, you can even use it to grab a creature to sacrifice to something like Fling or Goblin Bombardment. The fact that it untaps the creature as well can have its uses as well, and being able to use its abilities in a haste-like fashion can be brutal with things like Magus of the Disk.

2529: Ray of Erasure.author: Mode
2529: Ray of Erasure.text_parsed:
@Names_Suck: I think you're overstating the card a bit here.
You have a good point, but this card only gets useful if your opponent uses any topdecking control in the first place. No Brainstorm or Sensei's Divining Top or the like, and your opponent pretty much won't care about a single random card in his library hitting the graveyard.
Additionally, it's not a cantrip but a 'slowtrip', and that's another big disadvantage.

If even I could rather imagine this with some combo to target yourself, so you get something into the graveyard that you do want there. But Entomb will likely be an easier choice for that.

You have a good point, but this card only gets useful if your opponent uses any topdecking control in the first place. No [autocard]Brainstorm[/autocard] or [autocard]Sensei's Divining Top[/autocard] or the like, and your opponent pretty much won't care about a single random card in his library hitting the graveyard.
Additionally, it's not a cantrip but a 'slowtrip', and that's another big disadvantage.

If even I could rather imagine this with some combo to target yourself, so you get something into the graveyard that you do want there. But [autocard]Entomb[/autocard] will likely be an easier choice for that.

2530: Reality Twist.author: lukemol
2530: Reality Twist.text_parsed:
If they tap a green/black dual land, nothing special happens because it's neither a forest or a swamp and is thus unaffected.

Unless you're talking about the original dual lands that DO count as 2 types. Using your example of a green/black one, because it's a swamp it produces green and because it's a forest it produces black. So it still acts like it would normally. Also, note that unlike Naked Singularity, this card doesn't affect islands in any way.

I'm curious why they would decide to make 2 rare cards that are hard to use and cause the same sort of confusion, but are different card types within the same set. Does that seem logical?

Also, if both this and Naked Singularity are in play, I'm presuming the last one played is the one that has its ability used since it is a replacement effect in both cases.

2530: Reality Twist.author: Rayenous
2530: Reality Twist.text_parsed:
@ Oristi

That's not exactly true.

The effect of this card is a replacement effect.

Overgrown Tomb would technically be unchanged... when tapped for mana, either replacement effect could occur. As such (as it is with replacement effects), you may choose which replacement will occur... thus choosing which mana you receive.

It is important to note the difference, as a Hallowed Fountain is both an Island and a Plains. - This card would also have a replacement effect, but only one (the 'Plains is tapped for mana)... thus if you attempted to get Blue mana, the replacement would still cause it to produce Red mana only.

2536: Snow Devil.author: achilleselbow

2536: Snow Devil.text_posted: Ice Age had the most ridiculous specific restrictions on cards. You need snow-covered lands to get first strike WHEN BLOCKING. Because flying and first strike for 2 mana would have just been ridiculous...oh wait, [autocard]Wings of Aesthir[/autocard].

2536: Snow Devil.author: longwinded
2536: Snow Devil.text_parsed:
@achilles: Wings of Aesthir costs , which means a comparable blue-only cost would be something like . Since Flight is only , you are getting the first-strike-while-blocking for about as cheap as you could get it without making the card strictly better than Flight.

It also makes sense that you (and not any player) have snow lands out to trigger the ability. There's supposed to be some tension between the advantages and disadvantages of using snow lands, and this is supposed to be an advantage. However, if there's a good chance my non-island snow lands help someone else's blue deck be better, I probably would be reluctant to run them. By removing the enemy's lands from consideration, the ability can be seen universally as a benefit to running snow lands when constructing a deck.

The condition on blocking is a bit too restrictive for the cost, though. I'm pretty sure that's for flavor reasons. ("Hey, why does your guy benefit from the snow on your lands when he's attacking me through _my_ lands?")

2537: Snowfall.author: elhajjaj
2537: Snowfall.text_parsed: This card fueled Cumulative decks. Snowfall put additional mana into the pool, so its effects stacked when more than one were in play. 3 Snowfalls on the board could fuel a deck for quite a long time, with 7 mana available for each snow-covered land tap. A Skull of Orm helped recycle a Snowfall when the cost got too high. Illusionary Terrain , Musician, and even Illusions of Grandeur come to mind, and later a Mind Harness. Eon Hub eliminates upkeep, making some of these cumulative cards playable again. But Snowfall is what we used in the "olden" days...

2544: Word of Undoing.author: Salient

It might be fun to flip through sets since Ice Age to see if we're given more hints about the mysterious journal-keeper-who-kept-Uzra's-journals.

2546: Zur's Weirding.text_posted: Geez, this card is kind of unfun. My friend had a deck that gained 2 life per turn and locked out all draws, so unless you had some way to deal with it immediately (and dodge the inevitable counterspell,) you were done.

2546: Zur's Weirding.author: Aquillion
2546: Zur's Weirding.text_parsed:
Any sort of life gain capable of giving you two life a turn makes this an instant lock. Even without that, if you controlled the board when you played it, you're probably going to win unless your life total was very low -- if you're doing more than two damage to your opponent a turn, they're screwed.

The catch? It's kind of a win-more card, since you have to already be winning for it to really work.
2546: Zur's Weirding.text_posted:

Even without that, if you controlled the board when you played it, you're probably going to win unless your life total was very low -- if you're doing more than two damage to your opponent a turn, they're screwed.

The catch?  It's kind of a win-more card, since you have to already be winning for it to really work.

2550: Balduvian Bears.author: Technetium
2550: Balduvian Bears.text_parsed:
For those wondering why this card was made when they already had Grizzly Bears... the reason is the same as Fyndhorn Elves. This was the first set designed to be played without the need for cards from any other set. For whatever reason they considered Grizzly Bears an important staple in the base set, but didn't want to simply reprint the same card.

They chose to directly reprint cards like Dark Ritual and Counterspell because they recognized it would be a bad thing to give people 8 Dark Rituals or Counterspells in a deck outside of Ice Age Block.
2550: Balduvian Bears.text_posted:

They chose to directly reprint cards like Dark Ritual and Counterspell because they recognized it would be a bad thing to give people 8 Dark Rituals or Counterspells in a deck outside of Ice Age Block.

2551: Blizzard.author: TtothaOtothadoubleD
2551: Blizzard.text_parsed: @tankthebest: The early developers saw green as a card color that revolved around nature, not just forests and elves and flora and fauna. So things like Blizzards, Hurricanes, Tsunamis, even Snowblinds were all green, as they were manifestations of nature, albeit ones that involved lots of water. Somewhere along the way, the developers decided that Magic players were not sophisticated enough to connect elements of snow and winter with green's more general nature color (despite all relevant cultural references to nature and the environment as "green") and instead began associating all similar cards having to do with water, frozen or not, with the somewhat more intuitive blue. This is all nonsensical in the long run, but hopefully it at least explains why green got cards like Blizzard back in the good ol' days.
2551: Blizzard.text_posted: @tankthebest: The early developers saw green as a card color that revolved around nature, not just forests and elves and flora and fauna. So things like [autocard]Blizzard[/autocard]s, [autocard]Hurricane[/autocard]s, [autocard]Tsunami[/autocard]s, even [autocard]Snowblind[/autocard]s were all green, as they were manifestations of nature, albeit ones that involved lots of water. Somewhere along the way, the developers decided that Magic players were not sophisticated enough to connect elements of snow and winter with green's more general nature color (despite all relevant cultural references to nature and the environment as "green") and instead began associating all similar cards having to do with water, frozen or not, with the somewhat more intuitive blue. This is all nonsensical in the long run, but hopefully it at least explains why green got cards like Blizzard back in the good ol' days.

"I know, why don't we make it an enchant land, that makes the land tap to buff a creature until end of turn! And it's about forbidden lore, because that makes flavor sense... right?" "Okay, but only if I get to roll dice to see how much power and toughness you get!"

2560: Forbidden Lore.author: longwinded
2560: Forbidden Lore.text_parsed: This was supposed to be the offensive equivalent of Earthlore: Earthlore basically lets you tap a land to Holy Strength a creature, while Forbidden Lore lets you tap a land to Unholy Strength a creature. Knowing that explains what they were going for, but doesn't really fix it, flavorwise :/

2562: Foxfire.author: Tiggurix
2562: Foxfire.text_parsed: @Equinox523: I think the flavour is meant more as a dismissal of superstition. Foxfire (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Foxfire) is a real phenomenon. It's the bioluminescence of fungi that live in wood. This could easily lead to superstition among the uneducated around it, and thus learned people, such as this Archmage, would attempt to dismiss it, since foxfire is entirely harmless, and potentially useful.

2563: Freyalise Supplicant.author: DoctorKenneth

There have been quite a few cards with artist teams. G. Darrow and I. Rabarot teamed up for a few older cards, and Greg and Tim Hildebrandt have illustrated some more modern ones.

As for the card, thanks to Longwinded, I can now no longer see anything other than her fashioning kitten grenades. That is one odd cleric ability, especially when combined with the more humanoid white creatures.

Captain: "Cleric! What is going on here? We keep sending the camp's injured to you, but not a single soldier has survived! What sort of healing powers do you have, anyway?"
Cleric: "Alas, their injuries were far too grevious. There was nothing I could do."
Captian: "Very well. Can we at least have the bodies to bury?"
Cleric: "They're with the forest now."
Captain: "What?"
Cleric: "I set them on fire and catapulted them into the woods."

2565: Freyalise's Winds.author: Superllama12

2565: Freyalise's Winds.text_posted: I don't get this, can anyone explain it?  Do they not untap, and during their untap step instead of untapping them you take off the wind counter?

2565: Freyalise's Winds.author: SirMalkin
2565: Freyalise's Winds.text_parsed:
@Superllama12
Basically, once they tap they get a wind counter. Then, during your next untap phase, instead of untapping them, you remove the counter. Once they have no wind counters they'll untap as normal during the NEXT turn's untap phase...and the cycle repeats.
2565: Freyalise's Winds.text_posted:
@Superllama12
Basically, once they tap they get a wind counter. Then, during your next untap phase, instead of untapping them, you remove the counter. Once they have no wind counters they'll untap as normal during the NEXT turn's untap phase...and the cycle repeats.

2569: Fyndhorn Pollen.author: HuntingDrake
2569: Fyndhorn Pollen.text_parsed:
1) You're green, so your creatures are bigger. Who's worse off, the guy with two 6/6 -> 5/6's, or the guy with six 2/2 -> 1/2's?

2) It hits your opponents far harder than that; your attackers are only shrunk a little, but you pump a lot of mana into this on their turn, rendering their attackers worthless.

May have cumulative upkeep, but is the most affordable possible. Green should be able to keep this going a good long while.

2574: Johtull Wurm.author: PeabodyET
2574: Johtull Wurm.text_parsed:
@niceguy
I agree with you, but I'll correct what you said. If you're opponent blocks with 3 creatures, you still have a 2/4 wurm. It shrinks for each blocker beyond the first. You can easily kill 4 creatures with a decent combat trick on this wurm.

It's really not as bad as people are saying. If you have a Craw Wurm, and your opponent has a bunch of tokens, they will probably swing in with all but one guy, and leave the one back to chump your Wurm. If you have this guy though, they might hold back more guys in hopes of killing it with multiple blockers. So instead of getting hit with eight 1/1s, you're getting hit with three or four, or maybe none. Then when you swing in and they throw a bunch of blockers in front to shrink it, you pop out a combat trick and wipe their tokens.

I rate Johtull Wurm a 4.5 out of 5. He loses some value for being a worm in the rules text.

2576: Lhurgoyf.author: scumbling1
2576: Lhurgoyf.text_parsed:
"To Volcre, the old cards have way better art than the newer cards by far."

I disagree... somewhat. Magic has had tragic art failures in the past as much as it has it's tragic design failures. However, most of the abysmal artists responsible for the bad artwork have been replaced (Mark Poole, Justin Hampton and Fay Jones, off the top of my head). I think the art is held to a consistently higher standard nowdays. You can expect good results from newer artists like Aleksi Briclot and Jason Chan.

However, Magic no longer retains of few of their best artists: Richard Kane Ferguson, Harold McNeil, Anson Maddocks and Adam Rex. I think they were all victims of the new design policy of having more ***genized art. These artists all had a very distinct and stylized approaches to there work, and it doesn't fit in with the new policy. While recent cards feature many less blatantly ugly pieces of artwork, they lack the the overall variety and depth of some of Magic's best artwork from it's early years.

Now if we only could get Wizards to part ways with Ron Spencer, Pete Venters and Thomas Baxa...

2579: Nature's Lore.author: Nagoragama
2579: Nature's Lore.text_parsed:
Wow, this card is wacky.

First, you have a pretty standard land fetch, par for the course with green, called Nature's Lore, which makes sense for what the card does.

Then we have the art, which depicts a giant who seems pretty happy to have found an even more gigantic spider web in front of her. What does this have to do with lore? What does it have to do with fetching a land? It looks like someone put the wrong art on this card.

Then the flavor text, "Fyndhorn is our home." What does that have to do with lore or searching for a new land? Further it has nothing to do with the nonsensical art.

All in all, not a bad card, as it puts the forest on the battlefield untapped, but whoever designs the card layout must have been drunk that day.
2579: Nature's Lore.text_posted:
Wow, this card is wacky.

Then the flavor text, "Fyndhorn is our home."  What does that have to do with lore or searching for a new land?  Further it has nothing to do with the nonsensical art.

All in all, not a bad card, as it puts the forest on the battlefield untapped, but whoever designs the card layout must have been drunk that day.

2584: Rime Dryad.author: sonorhC
2584: Rime Dryad.text_parsed:
At the time, this was the only one-drop 1/2 without a drawback in the entire game, so it found its way into a number of weenie decks, even without regards to the landwalk.

But this kind of illustrates the entire problem with snow lands in Ice Age: Most of the things that interacted with them punished the player who was using them, and some of those things were worth using anyway, so there was basically no reason for anyone to ever put snow lands into their deck.

2586: Scaled Wurm.author: voyager1
2586: Scaled Wurm.text_parsed:
I can remember opening Ice Age boosters, hoping to open nothing more than a Scaled Wurm. He was the biggest creature I knew about, and therefore the best. When I opened that Polar Kraken instead I was disappointed, as even despite it's greater size, no f'ing way was I going to give him all that land! It wasn't nearly as handsome and regal as Scaled Wurm, either. I learned that there was a lot more to a creature than sheer size.

Sure, this realization taken further would lead me to avoid using cards like Scaled Wurm in the future. But it makes me ever more appreciative of the card; it was a big scaly step up on my way to becoming a better player.

Something to point out about 3 mana destruction, mostly that it's in green, is that you essentially have Sinkhole. You can start destroying turn 2 with no drawbacks and be in immediate control. 12 of these (winter's grasp, ice storm, beast within to cover anything else, including lands!) acidic slime, mold shambler.

By the time you're done with your starting hand of land destruction it should be about 5-6 lands to 1-2. If you haven't won yet.. I don't know.... get better?

2595: Touch of Vitae.author: Psuedonaut
2595: Touch of Vitae.text_parsed:
Passionate rant about an ambiguous card ahead.
I think this card is quite underrated. When do you need haste? Only on the turn that creature comes out, for that creature. There are tons of things that can be done to instants though, so it may normally be a one-time thing, but potentially much stronger in a combo. An obvious comparison for this is Instill Energy. Instill Energy is 2 cheaper, and gives a free untap every single turn, vs a much more expensive instant which happens to give actual haste, and gives you a card. So, one extra mana for the ability to play it instantly, which plays into the whole playing against an enemy and not for the most efficient thing, and then one extra mana for the card at the next turn's upkeep. Maybe I'm wrong about this next part, but maybe not, but it doesn't say the beginning of the next turn's first upkeep, so this might combo with Paradox Haze.

Back to comparisoning. A choice of Elvish Archdruid.
Instill Energy
Turn 1, Forest, Llanowar Elf.
Turn 2, Forest, Elvish Archdruid.
Turn 3, Forest, Llanowar, Llanowar, Llanowar, Instill Energy(Played later, so you can benefit from the double tapping of the archdruid. You can't do it earlier since attacking is different from tapping/using mana abilities). Tap the Elvish Archdruid for 5, tap him again for another 5. There's a total of 10 green mana in your mana pool. Of course, you're not going to get 4 llanowar's like that. And, assuming you drew turn 1, you have 1 card available to play. If you didn't, that 10 mana is useless, but turns into 17+ Turn 4.
Touch of Vitae
Turn 1, Forest, Llanowar Elf.
Turn 2, Forest, Llanowar, Llanowar, Llanowar.
Turn 3, Forest, Archdruid. Touch of Vitae, tap for 5, untap, tap again for another 5. You now have 11 mana, with 0 or 1 card(s). Also note, Turn 4 will give you only 12 mana. Yes, that's 5 less. Oh, by the way, that's 12 mana. With one card card advantage.

Of course, that's one example. the likelihood of having 3 Llanowar Elves turn 1, is, I know, lower than having 3 Llanowar elves turn 2. You can reduce the number of Llanowar's by 1, then they become equal, excluding the one card advantage that Touch has, and the turn 4+ mana advantage Instill has. I'm not even going to try factoring in other things, like kill cards or non-mana ramp decks, or anything else. It is definitely not the best card, I just want you to know, this card is better than 2.5, for sure.
Seriously. Lightning Blast, which is 3 colorless, one red, which does one more than Lightning Bolt, but costs 3 more colorless...? I don't really want to compare more, or argue that, but this card is 3+. So is Instill. It could be situationally amazing, and it could be bad. Lots of cards can be very bad if they aren't placed in the right deck, like putting Storm Crow in a mono black deck, or putting Chimney Imp and Storm Crow and Wood Elemental in a mono white deck. Doesn't mean the card's bad if the deck is.

Anyway, I decided to do a second comparison. This is without heavy mana producing, just simple stuff. As you can see, the mana cost weighs heavily. As in, VERY heavily.
Turn 1, Forest, Birds of Paradise.
Turn 2, Forest, Instill Energy, Any 3 card cost with 2 green/colorless and one of any color.
Or,
Turn 2, Forest, Any 2 card cost with 1 green/colorless and one of any color. Instill energy that creature for an early attack. My advice, use a Pygmy Hippo, and then steal whatever mana the enemy has. Could be 1, could be 2, could be a dead one drop, could be a dead pygmy and a dead 2 drop, could be a defender blocking.

Touch of Vitae
T1 Forest, Bird,
T2 Forest, ....nothing
T3 Forest, Bird, touch of vitae, tap the bird twice.... very depressing.

This can be broken down extremely simply. Instill energy pays for itself on the first turn on a mana producer, and has that availability on being placed on something aggressively to attack. Touch of vitae does not pay for itself if placed on a small mana producer, and you are essentially only paying for that extra card. It's situational. Not strictly worse. And not strictly bad.

2595: Touch of Vitae.author: PeabodyET
2595: Touch of Vitae.text_parsed:
@A3kitsune: Instill Energy doesn't actually give haste, it just lets the creature attack as though it had haste. Giving actual haste is better for a creature that you're going to get an extra untap out of. (Priest of Titania tapping twice the turn you play it??)

@Psuedonaut: Again, instill energy isn't worded the same, and the untap can only be used on your turn. And as an enchantment, it can only be played on your turn. Touch of Vitae, as an instant, could be used on your opponent's turn to untap a creature and block with it. And with this being a delayed cantrip, it replaces itself.

This card is much better utility than Instill Energy. As a combo piece, instill energy may be better, but this is a better card overall, in my opinion.

And @Thorns: Congratulations, you just invented a two-card, 4GBB cost, easily counterable Terminate (that can be regerated through).

2595: Touch of Vitae.author: DrJack
2595: Touch of Vitae.text_parsed:
The problem with Touch of Vitae is its mana cost. This card and Instill Energy are most often used on a creature you just summoned, of course, so you can attack right away with it (and then untap it afterwards to serve as a blocker!) So, Instill Energy, being a single green mana, means you just need 1 mana more than your creature's casting cost, but Touch of Vitae requires 3 extra mana. That makes a big difference, and means doing it later in the game, or just using it on tiny creatures. Sure, green has lots of fast mana, but it still takes time to get that mana available. Every point of mana is significant, otherwise Craw Wurm would be a great card.

Of course, the combos available with Instill Energy, the classics like Birds of Paradise and Prodigal Sorcerer, are another reason why the original mean green machine outclasses the hand with the spotty background. Long live Instill Energy!

But it has cool flavor. I mean think about it. It's pretty cool to imagine a game that has "trailblazers" as a fundamental type of creatures that are meant for getting through your opponent's defenses with ease and before the others.

Also i think some new players (or at least when this card was printed) would overrate this card and totally love it.
I used to have much respect for creatures that had powerful evasive abilities aside from flying to damage the opponent (like Shadow, Rhox's ability, or simply being unblockable.)

I also remember freaking out when i first saw Cloak of Mists and totally couldn't understand how this wasn't a rare card.
Which is kind of funny since Trailblazer is rare yet costs twice as much, is only temporarily and you can barely make use of the fact that it's an instant. (Some might now argue with the color pie and say it's rare because it's something green usually cannot do, but i'm not sure if this was regarded as off-color back then - we were still in the Ice Age :P)
But it seems Wizards had just as much respect for this game mechanic back then if you take a look at Teleport, which is very similar and seems to be the precursor of this in blue.
As a comparison: these days we get commons like Distortion Strike instead :D

2596: Trailblazer.text_posted:

2596: Trailblazer.author: Stinga
2596: Trailblazer.text_parsed:
@DrJack
CC means Converted Cost. That is all colorless mana plus the colored mana. This has CC four because 2 colorless+1 green+1green=4 total. Ball lighting is 3CC because R+R+R=3. If C was a color (like WUBRG) then you would be right. I have never tapped for C before though. If you are talking about color weight than that would be color weight of 2 (on this card) because it has two colored mana symbols.

2614: Chaos Lord.author: YotianSoldier
2614: Chaos Lord.text_parsed: I guessing that haste used to work differently. When this card was printed, a creature probably "came into play" when it changed controlers as well as when it was cast. It's haste looks to be worded so that the caster dosen't get haste but players that later gain control of it do. (otherwise it would suffer summoning sickness nearly every turn) Since changing controlers dosen't change the cards in-play status anymore his sudo-haste is redundant.  Thus, "looses haste untill end of turn".

2614: Chaos Lord.author: majinara
2614: Chaos Lord.text_parsed:
Creatures can't attack unless you controlled them since the beginning of your turn. If you gain control of the lord because of his ability, then you could normally NOT attack with him that turn, because you just control him since his triggered ability resolved during your upkeep, and not since the beginning of your turn. But since he has haste, you can attack with him that turn.

The point of him losing haste when he enters the battlefield the first time is to not let people attack with him the turn he comes into play. Instead, it's there to allow players to attack with him after the controller changed. Else the controller might change back and forth without anyone beeing able to attack.

All in all it's an interesting card imho, but the creature creep made a 7/7 first striker for seven mana pretty redundant. Today he'd have to be something like 10/10 trample first strike for the same amount of mana.

2614: Chaos Lord.author: jfre81
2614: Chaos Lord.text_parsed:
An old favorite from my earlier days playing. Always thought of this as the Lord of the Pit of red.

Got eight mana and you can finish 'em with a swing for seven? Go for it. Eight mana? Yes. Equip with Strider Harness for haste after you play him. And with some instant-speed burn/removal you can do a bit to try to keep the number of permanents an odd number when your upkeep rolls around. If you lose it, you can steal it back for your attack with Act of Treason.

It's hardly the best big red creature out there, but it's not horrible and it's dripping with red flavor.

2615: Chaos Moon.author: Mode
2615: Chaos Moon.text_parsed:
I gave this a 3/5 back in february 2009.

Now that this card's rating is even lower when i think about it again, i think this might be worth a 3.5.
All you need for it to work is a card that you can reliably switch from the battlefield to somewhere else, e.g. by using flicker effects. Or you could either use a sac outlet and/or a token maker.

If you have control of whether the effect works out or fires backwards, this can become more than just a potentially unreliable Gauntlet of Might - if you play against other monored decks, particularly if they don't run many instants, you can screw up their turn pretty badly as well.

2631: Jokulhaups.author: Lord_of_Tresserhorn

The correct spelling is Jökulhlaup. It is an Icelandic word which describes the outburst flood of a usually subglacial lake produced by the eruption of volcanoes under ice sheets, like Vatnajökull.

Also, a magnificent card. Almost total reset.

2635: Márton Stromgald.author: DarthParallax
2635: Márton Stromgald.text_parsed:
I hear people on Gatherer all the time say 'such and such would be a 6/6 for 6 and have trample nowadays' or 'so and so would have cost 7 mana back in the days and had a cumulative upkeep'.

well, ok, no not those specific remarks, but the sentiment we all know is there.

This guy though, he actually would be different stats for same mana, because he encourages attacking and blocking, but he dies whenever he does it. Wizards would be aware of his ability being fantastic these days, but Development is about 'making the game Fun' and Design is about 'making the cards do what you expect them to.' (if you believe what they say about themselves), and the way I read his ability, reads to me like a Dragon or a Titan.

He wants to attack. Give him Attacking numbers. Maybe, also, he'd become a 6 mana creature. for like a 4/5. Also, this ability in general feels more White than Red.

basically, it pretty much is Battlecry-- look at the Battlecry cards they actually made and compare them to Mr. Stromgald. He would not be a 1/1. But I could see a 2/2 Protection from Black, maybe?

He would be very different than what we see here if he were given a remake. Acually I think the Hellrider-like cards are what we get *instead* of trying to match this guy. They have better attack numbers, and the mana cost is aggressive, but then the ability is scaled back some.

We are constantly seeing new versions of this guy, we just don't recognize him anymore because he's tweaked to be more sensible and then tweaked again to be more fair.

If this guy was exactly as is but a 3/3, he'd be nuts. o.O

A card like this wouldn't necessarily be bad in a tournament like the one i was in because you knew people would probably have to play with snow covered land. Outside the tournament some cards from the set were like this where it was too specific making the card useless in most regular games. Why would you put this card in your deck when regular lands are so common. I rarely used snow covered land so why would i hope for my opponent to use them.

2638: Meteor Shower.author: nammertime
2638: Meteor Shower.text_parsed:
1 damage for 1 mana is better than Fireball and Rolling Thunder.
2 damage divided as you choose for 3 mana is better than Fireball for multiple targets and equal for one target, while being better than Rolling Thunder in every case.
3 damage divided as you choose for 5 mana is better than Fireball for multiple targets but worse for one target, as well as being exactly the same as Rolling Thunder in every case.
4 damage divided as you choose for 7 mana is better than Fireball for three or more targets, slightly worse for two targets (you only need to pay 6 mana for a two-target Fireball at 4 damage), and worse for one target. It is worse in every way to Rolling Thunder at this amount of mana investment.

Conclusion: It deserves a slightly higher average rating than what it's been given right now, if compared to both Fireball and Rolling Thunder's average ratings of around 4.5. Personally, I'm giving it a 3.5 to round out the rating, because it's just a different card, remaining versatile at low-mid mana costs, though probably not as useful as either Fireball or Rolling Thunder if you play with a large amount of mana available. It trades usefulness at high mana costs and even-numbered costs for being able to be played for 1 mana, I guess.
2638: Meteor Shower.text_posted:
1 damage for 1 mana is better than [autocard]Fireball[/autocard] and [autocard]Rolling Thunder[/autocard].
2 damage divided as you choose for 3 mana is better than Fireball for multiple targets and equal for one target, while being better than Rolling Thunder in every case.
3 damage divided as you choose for 5 mana is better than Fireball for multiple targets but worse for one target, as well as being exactly the same as Rolling Thunder in every case.
4 damage divided as you choose for 7 mana is better than Fireball for three or more targets, slightly worse for two targets (you only need to pay 6 mana for a two-target Fireball at 4 damage), and worse for one target. It is worse in every way to Rolling Thunder at this amount of mana investment.

Conclusion: It deserves a slightly higher average rating than what it's been given right now, if compared to both Fireball and Rolling Thunder's average ratings of around 4.5. Personally, I'm giving it a 3.5 to round out the rating, because it's just a different card, remaining versatile at low-mid mana costs, though probably not as useful as either Fireball or Rolling Thunder if you play with a large amount of mana available. It trades usefulness at high mana costs and even-numbered costs for being able to be played for 1 mana, I guess.

2657: Total War.author: Guest474596941
2657: Total War.text_parsed: This should be errata-ed to accommodate defender. Non-Wall creatures with defender will be destroyed, which, at the time of printing, couldn't happen. Considering Walls are one of the least printed things nowadays, it seems that this should address defender.
2657: Total War.text_posted: This should be errata-ed to accommodate defender. Non-Wall creatures with defender will be destroyed, which, at the time of printing, couldn't happen. Considering Walls are one of the least printed things nowadays, it seems that this should address defender.

2657: Total War.author: tavaritz
2657: Total War.text_parsed:
IMHO I don't think it should spare non-wall defenders.

The way I see it is that there is a fundamental difference between walls and non-wall defenders. Walls are immobile constructs or plants that need magic to animate, but non-wall defenders are homeguard that is only instructed not to attack. So non-wall defenders can be tempted to attack and when they try their commanders shoot them for deserters.

2658: Vertigo.author: Lord_of_Tresserhorn
2658: Vertigo.text_parsed:
Strictly less kinky than Earthbind.

But also awesome art!! I wonder if they asked around amongst the artists who really has acrophobia...

This is also probably the most coherent picture Drew Tucker ever did... :P (At least back then)

DT: I don't want to like this piece, but it was pretty successful. The composition gives it an uncontrollable spin, and it was exactly what I was shooting for.

MC: I can see why you might not want to like this one. It does not necessarily have the Tucker signature abstraction. But, like you said, it has a "spin" that just works. I actually think the hard lines (that you probably don't like) work to create the severe perspective and expanded depth of field in the piece. If you had softened background elements, it wouldn't be as successful.

From:

http://www.wizards.com/magic/magazine/Article.aspx?x=mtgcom/daily/mc64

ok so question....my friend attacked me with a 2/2 creature. i blocked with blinking sprit. then i try to bounce him back to my hand before damage is delt. i believe that blinking spirit wont die, and no damage will be dealt to any creature or player. i know you used to be able to do that when damage was on the stack, but did this change?
now my second question would be if you could bounce it back after damage is delt?
2668: Blinking Spirit.text_posted:
ok so question....my friend attacked me with a 2/2 creature. i blocked with blinking sprit. then i try to bounce him back to my hand before damage is delt. i believe that blinking spirit wont die, and no damage will be dealt to any creature or player. i know you used to be able to do that when damage was on the stack, but did this change?
now my second question would be if you could bounce it back after damage is delt?

2668: Blinking Spirit.author: OmegaSerris
2668: Blinking Spirit.text_parsed:
@schneidsc
You are correct. No damage is dealt. The M10 rule change basically just took away priority between the "deals damage" and "is dealt damage". Now it is just a single phase (Combat Damage) and the second event happens immediately after the first. Sort of like the Draw Step and Clean-up Step, no one gains priority during that part of Combat.

With current rules, the only way to "deal damage" and then having priority before your creature is attacked back is using First/Doublestrike. Even then, it follows the same rules. Damage is dealt and marked on the creature immediately.

BLINKY!!!

I have always loved this card, and not just because it could be used as a nigh unkillable blocker.

A long time ago, I was in love with a girl, and through some convoluted interactions, she got the personal pet name "Glowworm" from me... And once, I spent the night at her place, and deep in the night, I could not sleep, and I had this card with me, and scanned it on her computer, and set it as her desktop background. She loved it. :)

Though forever we will wonder why Blinky does not fly.

2678: Cooperation.author: Leshrac_Nightwalker
2678: Cooperation.text_parsed:
This card actually has a flavour-text partner in Elvish Healer. Again, when I was just a new player and I first realized that two different Ice Age cards had nearly identical flavour texts, I was puzzled at first. Once I realized that they depict mutual distrust between the elves and humans, and the slightly changed flavour text on each is supposed to highlight that, I was thrilled at having found a connection!

It's funny stumbling across it in Gatherer now, as it made me remember Elvish Healer almost immediately. Flavour text aside, the card seems unfortunately weak, but it has awesome Phil Foglio art to make up for it! Two stars from me for granting an unusual (and now rare) ability to any creature you like.

2680: Disenchant.author: Enchantment_Removal
2680: Disenchant.text_parsed:
It's not seldom that a player loses to one unanswered artifact or enchantment. Most unacceptable creatures have to attack or block to be a threat. More decks have an increased chance of dealing with such things.

However, there is pretty much one way of dealing with an enchantment or artifact that passively cuts you inconvenience.... and this is it. Lest everyone of your decks are curve-ball or tournament competitive, this should be main decked (or something equivalent in your color).

If you don't care about yourself, then think of others. Outside of your knowing, there may be other players who are happier than you can imagine that you ran artifact/enchantment removal. Just think about the last time you blew up a Bloodchief Ascension during a multiplayer game.

2683: Enduring Renewal.author: SanctusFumus
2683: Enduring Renewal.text_parsed:
Of all the magic cards, this card is without a doubt the card which is the most fun to play. There are literally hundreds of different ways a deck can be built around this card. It works great with any card which has a fun or powerful ability when it comes into play: Man-o'-War, Uktabi Orangutan, Trinket Mage, Wall of Blossoms,Mulldrifter etc.
Or any card which requires sacrifice: Recurring Nightmare,Ball Lightning, Claws of Gix, Hell's Caretaker, etc.
Alternatively this card works fantastically with creatures which are not always useful to have in play. Take Realm Razer or Peacekeeper for example. Play them each turn and sacrifice them at the end of your opponent's turn.
In fact this card can be combined with cards other than creatures. With cards like Titania's Song or Living Plane, artifacts and lands can be turned into creatures to protect them from destruction.

2686: Fylgja.author: Wprundv
2686: Fylgja.text_parsed:
From Wikipedia:

In Norse mythology, a fylgja (Old Norse, literally "someone that accompanies," plural fylgjur) is a supernatural being or creature which accompanies a person in connection to their fate or fortune. Fylgjur usually appear in the form of an animal and commonly appears during sleep, but the sagas relate that they could appear while a person is awake as well, and that seeing one's fylgja is an omen of one's impending death. However, when fylgjur appear in the form of women, they are then supposedly guardian spirits for people or clans
2686: Fylgja.text_posted:
From Wikipedia:

In Norse mythology, a fylgja (Old Norse, literally "someone that accompanies,"[1]  plural fylgjur) is a supernatural being or creature which accompanies a person in connection to their fate or fortune. Fylgjur usually appear in the form of an animal and commonly appears during sleep, but the sagas relate that they could appear while a person is awake as well, and that seeing one's fylgja is an omen of one's impending death. However, when fylgjur appear in the form of women, they are then supposedly guardian spirits for people or clans

2693: Kelsinko Ranger.author: longwinded
2693: Kelsinko Ranger.text_parsed:
You could make him an archer based on the image. You could make him a soldier based on the flavor text. You could make him a scout based on the "Ranger" name and fact that he's a combat trick on legs (gives a target first strike) like Icatian Scout, Advance Scout, or even Viashino Bladescout. The one thing it should NOT be is an ordinary human.

Mechanically, he seems most like a scout to me. He also doesn't have any "rangestrike" or anti-flier abilities, so mechanically the archer type just doesn't "click" with me. Just because he has a bow doesn't tell me he has to necessarily be an archer, first and foremost. This is also from a time when art, mechanics, and original idea were not expected to sync as well. This is not long after the aforementioned Icatian Scout was printed on a flying bat, despite not having flying.

You could make him a scout based on the "Ranger" name and fact that he's a combat trick on legs (gives a target first strike) like [autocard]Icatian Scout[/autocard], [autocard]Advance Scout[/autocard], or even [autocard]Viashino Bladescout[/autocard]. The one thing it should NOT be is an ordinary human.

Mechanically, he seems most like a scout to me. He also doesn't have any "rangestrike" or anti-flier abilities, so mechanically the archer type just doesn't "click" with me. Just because he has a bow doesn't tell me he has to necessarily be an archer, first and foremost. This is also from a time when art, mechanics, and original idea were not expected to sync as well. This is not long after the aforementioned Icatian Scout was printed on a flying bat, despite not having flying.

2701: Kjeldoran Warrior.author: sonorhC
2701: Kjeldoran Warrior.text_parsed:
chaosjuggler, I don't think you know what "strictly better" means. This is exactly the same as Benalish Hero unless creature type matters to you, and there's a lot more support for Soldier than for Warriors, so if anything, the Hero is better.

As for why Ice Age has so many functional reprints (see also Zuran Spellcaster or Fyndhorn Elves), it was the first time they decided that an expansion should be playable without the core sets, and there were a bunch of cards that were considered so integral to the game that they couldn't imagine an environment without them. Some, like the Circles of Protection, they just copied over with new art, but some they made functional reprints of.

Rings of Brighthearth + Basalt Monolith (or insert your favored infinite mana combo here.)

Step 4: Repeat Steps 2 and 3 four-hundred and ninety-nine more times.
Step 5: Rather than question marks and profiting, why don't you just go change the world now?
Step 6: Don't band them all when you attack.

2702: Lightning Blow.author: Equinox523
2702: Lightning Blow.text_parsed:
The great grand-daddy of white instant first strike/power pump pump spells (unless you count Rapid Fire, which I do not). It seems like the Ice Age developers overvalued how powerful this effect could be, and made it rare. These spells can be useful in limited environments, where seemingly even trades or even chump blocks can instead turn to your advantage. The fact that this one replaces itself with a slow cantrip makes it even better, though Guided Strike is strictly better if you prefer your card drawing instant.

To date, here are all mono-white variants of it:

Aerial Maneuver: , Gets +1/+1, flying and first strike until end of turn.
Guided Strike: , Gets +1/+0 and first strike until end of turn, draw a card (no delay).
Hundred-Talon Strike: , Gets +1/+0 and first strike until end of turn. Can be spliced to Arcane by tapping an untapped white creature you control.
Seize the Initiative: , Gets +1/+1 and first strike until end of turn.
Skillful Lunge: , Gets +2/+0 and first strike until end of turn.
Swift Justice: , Gets +1/+0, first strike and lifelink until end of turn.
Zealous Strike: , Gets +2/+2 and first strike until end of turn.

These spells can be useful in limited environments, where seemingly even trades or even chump blocks can instead turn to your advantage. To date, here are all mono-white variants of it:

2705: Order of the Sacred Torch.author: The_Jabberwocky
2705: Order of the Sacred Torch.text_parsed:
Very good card. Obviously its not optimal to just throw it in any deck, but this card is quite powerful when playing Rainbow Magic, or when you splash blue and can change the "black" to a color of your choice, or when you include this in your sideboard.

Also, I always found it quite bewildering how the card text says "destroy target black spell" but this card's opposite, Stromgald Cabal, from the same set, says to "counter target white spell." Somebody in the proof-reading department at Wizards was apparently sleeping when these cards went to print.

2705: Order of the Sacred Torch.author: Ruffigan
2705: Order of the Sacred Torch.text_parsed: As tcollins alluded, this card is incredible in a color change deck. Using instants like Sleight of Mind or Whim of Volrath; Swirl the Mists; Painter's Servant or Blind Seer; you can answer anything your opponents can cast for 1 life. Combine this with Northern Paladin and Southern Paladin, Lifeforce and Prophet of Kruphix or Seedborn Muse and you can basically run the board.

2706: Order of the White Shield.author: Equinox523
2706: Order of the White Shield.text_parsed:
This and its mirror Knight of Stromgald formed a mirrored pair that were functionally equivalent to Order of Leitbur and Order of the Ebon Hand from Fallen Empires. If any of you own an old deck box from Ice Age, at this point they were still trying to push the idea of playing it as a separate game, OR as a Magic expansion. This explains why cards that were functional reprints of stalwarts like Benalish Hero - in this case Kjeldoran Warrior - existed. But ultimately it just meant more pump knights for your white and black decks.

Now that time has passed, the fact that this is not a Cleric (and Leitbur being Oracle-updated to be both Knight and Cleric) makes this slightly worse. However, its still a fine card and one that can benefit from Knight Exemplar, which makes its low toughness more negligible.

A powerful ability, but it's very expensive. I like to imagine that when she resurrects opposing angels, she does not kill them, but simply uses her divine authority as one of the most powerful angels to command them to join your side.

Also, guys, it's not difficult to make her worth her exorbitant mana cost. For example, give her First Strike through Knighthood. Or even better, give her Double Strike through True Conviction, Fireshrieker, etc, and she'll potentially be able to steal twice as many creatures. Use cards such HIgh Ground, Blaze of Glory, etc, and she's arguably better than the aforementioned Adarkar Valkyrie, though I'll admit that the Valkyrie is probably easier to use.

2713: Snow Hound.author: Arachobia

@Mode

The reason it bounces only its allies but not white itself is that that was one of the themes of Ice Age: cards that interacted with their two ally colors.

Although as this was an old set most of the interactions weren't that useful, it is an interesting part of magics history as it was one of the earliest inter-color interaction cycles.

2714: Swords to Plowshares.author: tezcat
2714: Swords to Plowshares.text_parsed: It is an historical irony, and perhaps a color-pie travesty, that a targeted creature-removal spell could be among White's best cards of all time (and, conversely, that the arguably-best targeted creature-removal spell of all time is not Black). White is not exactly "bad" at removing creatures, it's just that it generally does so only in combat, when the creature is attacking or blocking, or does so without actually targeting anything (e.g. Wrath of God, Day of Judgment, Martial Coup). This spell has no built in targeting restrictions, occurs at instant speed, removes the creature from the game (overcoming Regeneration and Indestructible), and, most importantly, costs only 1 White mana. Considering all of the problems it solves and how quickly and easily it solves them, the drawback is negligible (and a mere afterthought considering the weakness of life-gain, in general).

2714: Swords to Plowshares.author: Starry_Night
2714: Swords to Plowshares.text_parsed:
It's a very powerful, even overpowered card, but it's not quite as dangerous when it's the only card of its type at that power level in a given environment. This was the case in Alpha and to a lesser extent in Ice Age. Like counterspells, cards like this only become really dangerous when you have a dozen of them in a format and they just make a linear deck that says "you can not has creature ever." The loss of popular cards like this and Lightning Bolt is an inevitable consequence of the design philosophy that new sets should have variants of everything and very little real innovation.

Orb of Insight forever

2717: Altar of Bone.author: DarthParallax
2717: Altar of Bone.text_parsed:
You have to remember that by the time Ice Age came out, most of this hadn't been invented yet.

The colors are wierd by OUR standards, no doubt there- out of curiosity, I tried thinking Devil's Advocate for the card though--

White is the color of balance. You should have to pay a creature to get exactly the creature you want?

Perhaps if this was gold hybrid, like the Alara Reborn 'blades', say G W/B, or B G/W, the cost would make more sense.

While the colors look 'wrong' to us today, I appreciate the attempt to balance tutoring with a meaningful cost. Maybe if sacrificing and discarding appeared as costs on more tutors, we could get them at nice mana costs again. That would limit the usefulness of Tutors to only the special decks that not only want, but need them, while at the same time making the cards even better for exactly those decks.

2719: Chromatic Armor.text_parsed:
1) Does not protect against doom blade.
2) Still can be chump blocked / evaded against.
3) Overall weak effect. Does not boost power nor grant evasion, just protects you against things that were supposed to kill you anyways rather then making you stronger.

Yeah you guys are probably sick of hearing about doom blade. On creatures this is a fair argument, but for auras this argument is needed. Getting 2 for 1 is a giant setback in magic, and this aura is super vulnerable to that common tactic. Almost forcing you to place this on a hexproof creature.

2722: Elemental Augury.author: blurrymadness

@Lavrant
Black and blue both manipulate the tops of libraries (however rare it may be), but that includes via milling/exiling cards, which is clearly {B}{U}. Manipulating the top can be seen in Misinformation and Portent.

The red? Don't know, this thing doesn't do anything but look at the top three (which is essentially a random assortment of 3 cards) so unlike some cards, like misinformation, or those that put target creature on top of a library, you have no control over what is there. This is a bit of a stretch, but the best I can do. This is "mildly chaotic" is what I'm trying to say.

2722: Elemental Augury.author: SkyknightXi
2722: Elemental Augury.text_parsed: The red is perhaps understandable in the form of messing with your opponent's card order, giving them a little taste of chaos. The revealing part was prefigured in Orcish Spy, anyway. As to the black...pure glue. Considering that this was printed at a time when WotC was REALLY looking at opposed color cooperation askance (notice that neither the Adarkar Wastes cycle nor the Land Cap cycle had any opposed color pairs), this, along with the other tricolors (Merieke ri Berit, Earthlink, Fiery Justice, and at least thematically, Storm Spirit) in the set, make much more sense if you think of them as actually UR, WB, BG, RW, and GU. But because of how intense WotC regarded color enmity then, they all needed their common allied color to be included as a mediator of sorts.

This card let you do 5 divided as you please. Already it is good enough. Any synergy with kavu predator or punishing fire is just gravy.

2729: Giant Trap Door Spider.author: Aaron_Forsythe
2729: Giant Trap Door Spider.text_parsed:
Aaron’s Random Card Comment of the Day #38, 11/16/11

The first thing that jumps out at me about this card is its name. “Trapdoor” is a compound word, and the name of the real animal this card is flavored as is “trapdoor spider.” Yet there it is, “Trap Door” with a space in the middle.

I’m guessing this was just a miss by an editor way back in the day, but the fact that there was (is?) a New York City literary society called the Trap Door Spiders (Isaac Asimov was perhaps its most famous member) makes me wonder if this wasn’t some kind of in-joke or homage.

The card itself is pretty solid considering it was released in Ice Age, although if it were designed today it would certainly have white as one of its colors, as exiling an attacker is about as white as it gets? (White-green? But that combo wouldn’t be weak to flyers. White-red? Maybe, but then it wouldn’t be a Spider. Tough call.)

For low-powered formats, I like it when cards like these have mana costs on their abilities, as it creates “pants-down moments” when it suddenly becomes safe to attack into it. If the ability was always active, your opponent would be forced to feed it one of his creatures before he could start attacking profitably and that kind of on-board pressure, while powerful, can get frustrating. Removal is often more fun from the hand, as it lends itself to tells, reads, and bluffs. Cards like the Spider here just force you to deal with it.

Typically when cards like this cost three mana to use, they aren’t good enough for constructed. But Olle Råde won the Ice Age block constructed Pro Tour with four copies of this in his deck, mostly for its “efficient” body--an indictment of the power level of creatures at that time.

Giant Trap Door Spider was reprinted in Invasion with a different creature type as Hunting Kavu. In cases such as this one, the design team typically wants to reprint the original card name and all, and the creative team wants to reskin it to reinforce the world-building, in this case the introduction of the Kavu creature type. Were it up to me at the time, I’d take the opportunity that renaming the card gave me to tweak the ability and/or numbers. If you can’t have nostalgia, you might as well have a better card.

2729: Giant Trap Door Spider.author: The_Trendkill
2729: Giant Trap Door Spider.text_parsed:
I love this card. As a Timmy, it's one of the few 'tricks' out there that I find absolutely hilarious. I guess that's mostly because it isn't really a trick. In fact, it's more of a really obvious hole in the ground. Call me crazy/weird/whatever, but I find something novel about blatantly obvious on-board removal.

Also, the name. I started playing Magic with Eighth Edition, so when I started I had never seen any of these older cards before. Strangely, this was the first card I ever saw in an old frame, as well as the first multicolored card I saw. It looked ridiculous, even its name. Four words long? And the mana symbols didn't look quite the same. I thought it was fake.

2732: Kjeldoran Frostbeast.author: Chrysologus
2732: Kjeldoran Frostbeast.text_parsed: I agree with Titantium Dragon. The card's updated (9/3/09) Oracle wording, while retaining the printed wording of the card from 1994, does not function under 2009 rules as the card originally did in 1994. To maintain original functionality, it should revert to its pre-9/3/09 wording, which is the same as that of Thicket Basilisk (which still functions correctly thanks to having been reprinted in 5th Ed.). I sent Gottlieb an email about this, so hopefully he will change it back.

2732: Kjeldoran Frostbeast.author: The_Jabberwocky
2732: Kjeldoran Frostbeast.text_parsed:
Hide Rulings
10/1/2009 Kjeldoran Frostbeast's ability triggers only if it's still on the battlefield when the end of combat step begins (after the combat damage step). For example, if it blocks a 7/7 creature and is destroyed, its ability won't trigger at all. The 7/7 will remain on the battlefield.
10/1/2009 Its ability will destroy all creatures it's currently blocking or blocked by, not necessarily the creatures it had blocked or become blocked by during that combat phase. For example, if Kjeldoran Frostbeast is dealt lethal combat damage and regenerates, it's removed from combat. Its ability will trigger at end of combat, but since it's no longer blocking or blocked by any creatures, the ability won't do anything.

These rulings are depressing and ruin this card. It was clearly meant to function the same as Thicket Basilisk when Ice Age went to print. It requires 2 different colored mana rather than only 1 so its perk was to not have the wall restriction. As mentioned by others, the identical wording on the 4th edition Thicket Basilisk proves this point. WotC gets 0/5 stars for this lame decision.

2737: Skeleton Ship.author: Lord_of_Tresserhorn
2737: Skeleton Ship.text_parsed:
This seems to me to be a clear case of touching a powerful ability while wearing a fullscale hazmat suit.

- It's a legend, even if it's not really flavorful at all (at least give it a proper name!)
- It has a kind of semi islandhome.
- It's utterly worthless in combat and not even that good as a blocker.
- It's not boltproof.

All this to offset what is a good but not ridiculous ability.

Printed today, this would probably have a name, still be a legend, be mythic, be 4/4, have islandwalk and swampwalk, and put -1/-1 counters on all creatures except itself.

Though it's probably fun to play with Freed from the Real.

2740: Stormbind.author: Equinox523
2740: Stormbind.text_parsed: This card did something fundamentally different to the game - it transformed the cards in your hand into a resource that could be exploited. Rather than just viewing them as spells and lands, they were now inconsequential ammo that you could just trade for damage. At instant speed, and spending colorless mana to activate, suddenly Wheel of Fortune meant : restock your ammo. As long as you had the mana, even late-game Mountains were now an expendable source of damage. This provided red with a way to break combat stalemates, and a way of getting damage in even when it was drawing only lands and junk.
2740: Stormbind.text_posted: This card did something fundamentally different to the game - it transformed the cards in your hand into a resource that could be exploited.  Rather than just viewing them as spells and lands, they were now inconsequential ammo that you could just trade for damage.  At instant speed, and spending colorless mana to activate, suddenly [autocard]Wheel of Fortune[/autocard] meant [2][R]: restock your ammo.  As long as you had the mana, even late-game [autocard]Mountain[/autocard]s were now an expendable source of damage.  This provided red with a way to break combat stalemates, and a way of getting damage in even when it was drawing only lands and junk.

2750: Adarkar Wastes.author: themicronaut
2750: Adarkar Wastes.text_parsed:
For those of us who couldn't (or still can't) afford dual lands, the Ice Age painlands opened up a whole new world of decks and color combos. I think there is a point in every magic players life where they realize that taking damage can be a good thing, and that gaining life by itself is quite pointless. Using these cards separates the newbies from the intermediate players, and they are crucial elements of any 2+ color deck back in the day (or today).

Also, the artwork is beautiful!

4.5/5

2750: Adarkar Wastes.author: DarthParallax
2750: Adarkar Wastes.text_parsed:
Painlands....yeah, they're not bad. To be honest, they've been passed by so many times over it's sad. The biggest tickler for me is that they're Rares. They just are not that good- no, I'm not even listening to ''Dual Lands are always good!" arguments. These are EXACTLY where Uncommon Lands in the game should always have been.

Arabian Nights- no colored lands except City of Brass...which is nice at Rare. :)
Antiquities- no....colors. alright fine that was ONE special case. :P
LEGENDS- THIS is the big problem: they didn't include any good enough mana-fixing in, of all places, the first (and dare-I-say BEST) Multicolored Set Ever?! WHAT?
The Dark- Blood Moon and Red started to be a thing and some stuff here and there but....few good cards.
Fallen Empires- still no good lands.
Ice Age
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

The first Tri-Lands wouldn't be seen until Homelands, and they were so terrible only Castle Sengir gets played because...come on...that flavor is pretty rad. XP
But quite seriously, Legends should have had 10 Uncommon Dual Lands and 5 Rare Tri-Lands and would have had it been Re-Designed and Developed today.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

These would be 4 stars for Power and Need, but it's a glaring hole that players didn't get anything like this in Legends, the Dark, Fallen Empires, OR Fourth Edition. 3.5/5 stars because they didn't know better back then, but that's sad.

2754: Ice Floe.author: Khardiss
2754: Ice Floe.text_parsed:
@leomistico - Incorrect. You cannot use Ice Floe to tap 2 (or more) creatures. You use Ice Floe to prevent a creature that attacks you from untapping as long as your Ice Floe doesn't untap. If you use Tidewater Minion to untap your Ice Floe, then the creature you had trapped will be released and will untap during it's owners next untap phase. You would only be able to trap one creature. Also, Ice Floe does not stop the attack. When your opponent attacks you, you use Ice Floe to prevent his creature from untapping, but that attacking creature still attacks. You still need to block it or take the damage from it.

@PlagueWielder - How is Ice Floe a poor man's Maze of Ith? They're basically exactly opposite of each other. Maze of Ith untaps attacking creatures and prevents all damage, Ice Floe prevents attacking creatures from untapping and does nothing to prevent damage.
2754: Ice Floe.text_posted:

If you use [autocard]Tidewater Minion[/autocard] to untap your Ice Floe, then the creature you had trapped will be released and will untap during it's owners next untap phase. You would only be able to trap one creature. Also, Ice Floe does not stop the attack. When your opponent attacks you, you use Ice Floe to prevent his creature from untapping, but that attacking creature still attacks. You still need to block it or take the damage from it.

@PlagueWielder - How is Ice Floe a poor man's [autocard]Maze of Ith[/autocard]?  They're basically exactly opposite of each other.  Maze of Ith untaps attacking creatures and prevents all damage, Ice Floe prevents attacking creatures from untapping and does nothing to prevent damage.

2761: Underground River.author: Carnophage_4ever
2761: Underground River.text_parsed:
Carnophage's Dual Lands Scale

1st - Original Dual Lands - By a land slide, no drawback except the 4 copies limit;
Distant 2nd - Ravnica lands - You can choose if you get the 2 dmg or not;
Tied at 3rd - M10/M11 Lands - Act as dual lands if you have corresponding basic land in play, no dmg
Tied at 3rd - Scars of Mirrodin Dual Lands - Act as dual lands when you're Manaskrewd or on first 2 turns, less $$$, grab em now!
4th - Shards of Alara Triple Color lands - Come in tapped. 3 color possibility.
5th - Underground River, Shivan Reef, etc. - No tap, colorless, but damage for color mana
6th - Guildpact Lands - Give 2 colored mana, come in tapped, bounce other lands
7th - Homeland Lands - Dont even bother, they're as awful as awful can be.

Of course, we're talking dual-color lands, not legendary lands or utility lands, like Urborg or Maze of Ith. Of course it's arguable for some positions depending on what you want to play, but positions 1 and 2 ARE NOT ARGUABLE.
2761: Underground River.text_posted:

2774: Snow-Covered Plains.author: Tivoko

Snow lands can be useful when using Extraplanar Lens if you are playing against a deck that uses the same color(s) as you since people rarely play Snow Lands.
